title: England considering imposing a 'tourist tax' on accommodation | ABC NEWS
description: The British Parliament is considering charging visitors a nightly "tourist tax" on all accommodation across England.   Under the proposed legislation councils would be able to charge a flat fee or a percentage of an overnight stay and both local and international tourists would pay the levy, raising millions for mayors to invest infrastructure and transport.   Social version by Tatenda Chibika for the ABC News Social Media Team.   ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: One dead, thousands without power after extreme weather lashes NSW | ABC NEWS
description: Ferocious weather has lashed much of NSW with storms, wild winds, and extreme heat across the state. A 76-year-old man has died on the Central Coast after he was struck by a falling tree. Meanwhile, Sydney's train network was disrupted by the wild weather, and other parts of the state saw conditions that made for a catastrophic fire risk. title: US revokes immigration status for Myanmar citizens, claims nation is 'safe' | The World | ABC News
description: The US Government is planning to strip thousands of Myanmar nationals living in America of their temporary immigration status. The Trump administration cites elections planned by the ruling military junta as evidence the situation in the warn-torn country is improving - hence safe for citizens to return. Thomas Kean, senior consultant on Myanmar and Bangladesh with the International Crisis Group, told The World's Girish Sawlani the White House's assessment is far from reality. title: UK justice secretary proposes scrapping juries | The World | ABC NEWS
description: UK Justice Secretary David Lammy is proposing to massively restrict the ancient right to a jury trial by only guaranteeing it for defendants facing rape, murder, manslaughter or other cases passing a public interest test. The proposal drew backlash from senior lawyers who feared it could fundamentally alter the justice system. Head of immigration and public law at 33 Bedford Row chambers Dr S Chelvan joined The World from London. title: Mother sentenced to life in prison for New Zealand's 'suitcase murders' | ABC NEWS
description: *Warning: This story contains details that may be distressing for some users.*  Hakyung Lee, the New Zealand mother who murdered her children and hid their bodies in suitcases at an Auckland storage facility, has been sentenced to life in prison.  Lee was found guilty of killing the children, then changing her name and flying to South Korea.  High Court judge Geoffrey Venning today sentenced Lee to life imprisonment with a minimum non-parole period of 17 years, saying she had killed children who were "particularly vulnerable".  *If you or anyone you know needs help:*  Suicide Call Back Service on 1300 659 467 Lifeline on 13 11 14 13YARN on 13 92 76 Kids Helpline on 1800 551 800 Beyond Blue on 1300 224 636 Headspace on 1800 650 890 ReachOut at au.reachout.com MensLine Australia on 1300 789 978 QLife 1800 184 527  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Rate hikes possible in 2026, warns CBA chief economist | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: Inflation accelerated more than expected in the year to October, according to new monthly figures. The measure the Reserve Bank looks closely at, the trimmed mean rose to 3.3 per cent, which is now higher than its target range. The RBA's target range is between 2-3 per cent. Headline inflation, at 3.8 per cent came in higher than market expectations, 3.6 per cent. Some economists think the easing cycle over, while others are warning of volatility in the data.  Commonwealth Bank's chief economist Luke Yeaman is warning that Australia's economy is running close to full speed, creating a headache for the Reserve Bank.  He says stronger growth, a resilient labour market, rising house prices and an inflation surprise in the September quarter and October monthly quarters have taken rate cuts off the table and raised the risk of hikes in 2026.  He thinks Australia is "getting close to our economic speed limit", with potential growth now lower.   Speaking to ABC TV's The Business, Mr Yeaman said "the question is where to from here into 2026? Do they (the RBA) need to take out a little bit more insurance to keep inflation under control?"  "Our view is that when you look through the inflation surprises that we've had some of those factors driving that are temporary, and some of them look a little more persistent, but there are definitely some temporary factors at play too. So we're still hopeful that as we move into 2026, we'll start to see the economy stabilise and inflation come back towards the target band. But there are certainly risks mounting on the upside."  Even though energy prices have rose on an annual basis by 37 per cent to October, Mr Yeaman says while it impacts households, the Reserve Bank isn't concerned about energy prices, they're "looking through it". #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad.
